title: Shell completion dependent on arguments already given
body:
It would be great to have shell completion that can depend on commands, options, and arguments that have already been specified on the command line. Right now, I see that `ctx.params` does not include them, and this is, as far as I can tell, the right behaviour. However, consider the following example.

`./foo.py --global-opt foo my_command --command-opt <TAB>`

There is no good solution (as far as I can tell) in the case the tab completion options for `--command-opt` depend on the value of `--global-opt`, for example. So, it would be good to be able to do processing for `--global-opt` first, before doing shell completion for `--command-opt`.

title: Option to force ANSI color codes or disable TTY detection
body:
[ANSI Colors](https://click.palletsprojects.com/en/8.1.x/utils/#ansi-colors) are automatically disabled in some cases, I would like to request some option to disable this feature for cases where the output may be captured outside of a TTY but color codes are still desired.

Specific use case: GitLab CI [supports color codes in output](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/yaml/script.html#add-color-codes-to-script-output), however Click applications don't appear to output color codes when executed in this context.

title: Documentation of decorators should should show where to look for arguments' reference
body:
I've just started exploring click, and wholeheartedly love it. Thanks!

One thing that made the experience a bit frustrating was the API reference. Currently, in some places, it omits descriptions of the arguments of some of the decorators. For example, with [`click.argument`](https://click.palletsprojects.com/en/8.1.x/api/#click.argument), it just says the type is `Any` without telling where to look for the actual description:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6691643/167310684-18074b81-3932-4bc8-b7e4-5af48cf8f8b2.png)

I guess it's because the underlying argument class is customizable, but for the default usecase it would be nice to have a reference to the default.

Clicking on the reference to [`click.Argument`](https://click.palletsprojects.com/en/8.1.x/api/#click.Argument) doesn't reveal much either:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6691643/167310805-d624ec5c-728a-4f73-9f72-43c7a86ee9c9.png)

It would be nice if the description of `attrs` pointed to their actual reference: [`click.Parameter`](https://click.palletsprojects.com/en/8.1.x/api/#click.Parameter) in case of `argument` and `option` decorators.

There's already a precedent for this in the docs - [`click.Group`](https://click.palletsprojects.com/en/8.1.x/api/#click.Group):
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6691643/167312103-295a3eee-42c7-436a-a2e0-cbbaebb001b0.png)

title: Possibility to see if the command definition changed
body:
I looked a bit and I could not find it, but I wonder if there is a possibility to determine if any of the definitions of the click commands changed since last time we run the check.

This woudl be extremely useful for generating documentation automatically as part of pre-commit/CI workflow. We are doing that in Apache Airflow, resulting in embedded SVG images like this : https://github.com/apache/airflow/blob/main/BREEZE.rst#installation

Currently the (small) problem we have is that we always try to regenerate those SVG images in CI and we fail pre-commit if the generated images are different. This allows us to make sure that we have not forgotten to regenerate and SVG image when any parameter changes. And it works moslty fine (we've made sure that terminal size is always the same when we generate the help so re-geenerated images are the same). The problem is when output format of the SVG changes (as it happened in rich 12.4.0 for example) - because then the generated SVG images will be slightly different. We do not really want to pin rich and upgrade it manually as this is just a development tool in this case, but this is what we ended up for now.

The simple solution to that would be to get some kind of unique hash that would only change if any of the parameters, their help, type etc. changes - and otherwise being stable. Then we could implement such workflow (automatically):

* Check if current hash of all options/commands/flags has not changed from the last one committed together with images. Skip the rest if it did not.
* Generate images only if hash is different
* Store the changed hash
* Commit both - generate SVG and hash together

This way we could actually only run the SVG generation if we know any of the options changed (the problem currently is that we generate it every time any of the "dev" python code changes which is quite excessive - but since `click` annotations are part of the code, that's simplest.

Is there such a feature already available and I missed it ? Or if not - do the maintainers think it's a good idea? I am willing to contribute a PR for that - I might be able to analyse the code and find out how to do and maybe need a little guidance, but I would love to know if that seems like a good idea.

title: Support custom shell behaviors for autocompletion
body:
Bash supports two custom behaviors that are helpful to our application: 

* the ability to change what defines a word break
* the ability to not emit a space when a matching completion is found

We add this behavior to the click-generated bash script like so:

```
    local IFS=$'\n'
    local response

    response=$(env COMP_WORDS="${COMP_WORDS[*]}" COMP_CWORD=$COMP_CWORD _GUILD_COMPLETE=bash_complete $1)

    COMP_WORDBREAKS='"'"'"'><=;|&(: '  # Reset as can be modified below.
    for completion in $response; do
        IFS=',' read type value <<< "$completion"
        if [ "$value" = "!!nospace" ]; then
            compopt -o nospace
            continue
        elif [ "$value" = "!!no-colon-wordbreak" ]; then
            # Dangerous as this effects other completions. The damage
            # is mitigated by resetting COMP_WORDBREAKS above but this
            # is still not ideal.
            COMP_WORDBREAKS='"'"'"'><=;|&( '
            continue
        fi
        if [[ $type == 'dir' ]]; then
            COMPREPLY=()
            compopt -o dirnames
        elif [[ $type == 'file' ]]; then
            COMPREPLY=()
            compopt -o default
        elif [[ $type == 'plain' ]]; then
            COMPREPLY+=($value)
        fi
    done
```

We then use custom shell_complete functions in python to emit these values (`!!nospace` or `!!no-colon-wordbreak`) where we want to enable those behaviors. We use psutil to detect the parent shell, and when that is bash, we emit these strings.

Would this be of interest to include in click? If so, I'd be happy to add it and document it. I'm just not sure if it is too bash-specific to be in click, and also pretty sure the psutil dependency would be too much to ask.

title: invoked_subcommand is always None in option callback on group with given subcommand
body:
When defining an option with a callback on a `Group` the `invoked_subcommand` attribute in the `Context` passed to the callback is always `None` even if a subcommand was indeed passed.

Minimal example:

```python
import click

def cb(ctx, param, value):
    print(f'callback {ctx.invoked_subcommand=}')


@click.group()
@click.option('-o', callback=cb)
@click.pass_context
def main(ctx, o):
    print(f'group {ctx.invoked_subcommand=}')


@main.command()
def cmd():
    ...

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
```

Run with `python file.py cmd`

Actual output:
```
callback ctx.invoked_subcommand=None
group ctx.invoked_subcommand='cmd'
```

Expected output:
```
callback ctx.invoked_subcommand='cmd'
group ctx.invoked_subcommand='cmd'
```


Environment:

- Python version: 3.9.2
- Click version: 8.1.3

title: Pass 'color' explicitly in error echoing
body:
<!--

* This fixes the error reported in https://github.com/pallets/click/issues/2193. Since the context has been popped at the point the error is printed, `resolve_color_default` incorrectly returns `None` and so the color is stripped from any color in error messages. This PR caches that setting in the `ClickException` initialization and then passes it to the `echo` later on, thereby bypassing this check at the failing point

title: Add EnumChoice type
body:
<!--
Before opening a PR, open a ticket describing the issue or feature the
PR will address. Follow the steps in CONTRIBUTING.rst.

Replace this comment with a description of the change. Describe how it
addresses the linked ticket.
-->

* Add `EnumChoice` `ParamType` that inherits from the `Choice` type. It can take an `enum.Enum` and use it's keys or values as options that can then be mapped back to the enum itself.
* Allows enum keys or values to be used as the choices

Example Usage:
```py
    class MockEnum(Enum):
        foo = 1
        bar = 2
        baz = 3

    @click.argument("method", type=click.EnumChoice(MockEnum))
    def cli(method):
        click.echo(method)
```

title: Use t.Mapping not t.Dict for parameters
body:
https://docs.python.org/3/library/typing.html#typing.Dict
> To annotate arguments it is preferred to use an abstract collection type such as Mapping.

This PR does almost that to fix the issue below.  I instead use `MutableMapping` here since we do mutate in some cases.  I chose to use `MutableMapping` everywhere for consistency and leaving it open for more mutation in the future.  I understand that this may not be preferred and would be happy to use `Mapping` where possible instead.

- fixes #2264

It was suggested I could follow https://github.com/pallets/click/pull/2256 as a guide for how much of this checklist applies to hint-only changes.  As such some have been skipped.

title: Unable to properly inherit and hint Group due to use of Dict for parameters
body:
I am working on updating to Click 8 in https://github.com/Chia-Network/chia-blockchain/pull/11361 and wanted to make `windows_expand_args=True` default for all my uses and have a single place to apply any other adjustments I need at that level.  I wrote a custom subclass of `Group` as below to achieve that, as well as a similar subclass of `Command`.  The issue is that when I hint that only my `_Command` subclass should be passed mypy complains due to the variance of `Dict`.  Modifying `click.Group.__init__()` to accept `Mapping[str, Command]` instead of `Dict[str, Command]` resolves the issue.  I will submit a PR immediately following this.

```
chia/util/click.py:22: error: Argument "commands" to "__init__" of "Group" has incompatible type "Union[Dict[str, _Command], Sequence[_Command], None]"; expected "Union[Dict[str, Command], Sequence[Command], None]"  [arg-type]
```

```python
class _Group(click.Group):
    def __init__(
        self,
        name: Optional[str] = None,
        commands: Optional[Union[Dict[str, _Command], Sequence[_Command]]] = None,
        **attrs: Any,
    ) -> None:
        # _commands = cast(Optional[Union[Dict[str, click.Command], Sequence[click.Command]]], commands)
        super().__init__(name=name, commands=commands, **attrs)
        self.command_class = _Command

    def main(
        self,
        args: Optional[Sequence[str]] = None,
        prog_name: Optional[str] = None,
        complete_var: Optional[str] = None,
        standalone_mode: bool = True,
        **extra: Any,
    ) -> Any:
        return super().main(
            args=args,
            prog_name=prog_name,
            complete_var=complete_var,
            standalone_mode=standalone_mode,
            windows_expand_args=True,
            **extra,
        )
```

Environment:

- Python version: 3.10.1
- Click version: 8.1.3

title: Mark parameter as deprecated
body:
Thanks for this great project!
Perhaps it's just me who feels that it is rather cumbersome mark a single parameter as deprecated (the closet I found was https://stackoverflow.com/a/50402799). Is there perhaps a more official method to mark a single parameter as deprecated?
That would somewhat be similar to https://github.com/pallets/click/issues/1507.

Possible scenarios:
- the parameter was renamed (e.g. a previous version was using `--name` as option, but now a dev want's to make sure it's the `--sur-name`.
- the parameter is not needed anymore

Perhaps as an example consider:
```
import click

@click.command()
@click.option('--count', default=1, help='Number of greetings.')
@click.option('--name', prompt='Your name',
              help='The person to greet.')
def hello(count, name):
    """Simple program that greets NAME for a total of COUNT times."""
    for x in range(count):
        click.echo(f"Hello {name}!")

if __name__ == '__main__':
    hello()
```
and I want to rename `--count` to `--greetings-count`.
However I don't want to remove  `--count`  instantly, instead when users use `--count` prompt a message that they should use the new `--greetings-count`. The usage of `--count` and `--greetings-count` should be forbidden.

Thanks.

title: colorama dependency in Pipfile.lock containing windows marker because click
body:
Hi guys,

Today I was testing one flask service which is using flask-cors and pytest-cov and behind the curtains these ones are using click. 
We're using pipenv to install this service and we've noticed one of the subdependencies,
colorama is being marked to be windows specific in the Pipfile.lock, ie:

```
        "colorama": {
            "hashes": [
                "sha256:5941b2b48a20143d2267e95b1c2a7603ce057ee39fd88e7329b0c292aa16869b",
                "sha256:9f47eda37229f68eee03b24b9748937c7dc3868f906e8ba69fbcbdd3bc5dc3e2"
            ],
            "markers": "platform_system == 'Windows'",
            "version": "==0.4.4"
        },
```
I've tried to understand what was the rationale behind this and it seems is because click is marking it as windows dependecy, ie:
[https://github.com/pallets/click/pull/1784/commits](https://github.com/pallets/click/pull/1784/commits)

This looks like a bug. Colorama [is a cross-platform dependency](https://github.com/tartley/colorama/blob/master/setup.py#L53) so the fact you're marking it as windows specific it's a bug
that will prevent from generating cross-platform Pipfile.lock when using tools such as pipenv. So because of that the library won't be installed in CI envs unless flagging colorama with a "fake" marker, which it's a workaround in the first place.

Thanks.

title: Callback on options fires twice
body:
Minimum code to reproduce:
```python
from pprint import pprint

import click


def handler(ctx, param, value):
    ctx.obj = {}
    print("handler has been fired")
    match value:
        case "time":
            input_value = click.prompt("Select input for time", type=str)
            ctx.obj["input_value"] = input_value
        case "quantity":
            input_value = click.prompt("Select input for quantity", stype=int)
            ctx.obj["input_value"] = input_value
    return value


@click.group()
def cli():
    return


@cli.command()
@click.option(
    "--an-option",
    prompt=True,
    type=click.Choice(["time", "quantity"]),
    callback=handler,
)
@click.pass_context
def test_command(ctx, **kwargs):
    pprint(ctx.obj)
    pprint(kwargs)


if __name__ == "__main__":
    cli()
```
output
```
python cli.py test-command
An option (time, quantity): time
handler has been fired
Select input for time: 10
handler has been fired
Select input for time: 10
{'input_value': '10'}
{'an_option': 'time'}
```
We can see that the message "handler has been fired" shows up twice.

title: Fix typing on command and group decorators
body:
This PR adds generics to the `typing.Callable` type hint inside the command and group decorators.

title: Help text wrapping set to 80 irrespective of the terminal width
body:
According to the [documentation](https://click.palletsprojects.com/en/8.1.x/documentation/#preventing-rewrapping) click should:

> The default behavior of Click is to rewrap text based on the width of the terminal

At least on a mac terminal, that's not the case.  For me, the output of `shutil.get_terminal_size()` is `os.terminal_size(columns=210, lines=44)`.  But click is wrapping all text to 80 characters and does not respond to resizes of the terminal before or during the program's execution.

This is a little jarring and it would be nice if this could either dynamically resize or offer a way to manually set it.

Environment:

- Python version: 3.9
- Click version: 8.1.2

title: Click Should Support Mutually Exclusive Options
body:
Description
========
More often than none you want to add few options to a CMD such that at most one of them can be set with a value. This ability can be achieved by setting a group of mutually exclusive options.

Suggested API
==========

Here's a suggested API for this ability
```python
import click

@click.command()
@click.mutually_exclusive(
    click.option("-a", type=int, help="This is a"),
    click.option("-b", type=str, help="This is b"),
    click.option("-c", is_flag=True, default=False, help="This is c"),
    required=True,
)
def my_command(a, b, c):
    click.echo(f"{a=}, {b=}, {c=}")


if __name__ == "main":
   my_command()
```

In this example we define three mutually exclusive options: `-a`, `-b` and `-c`. With setting `required=True` we determine that at least one of them should be set (default is `False`).

The following should be printed:
```
>> my-command -a 5
a=5, b=None, c=False
>> my-command -b hello
a=None, b=hello, c=False
>> my-command -c
a=None, b=None, c=True
>> my-command -a 5 -b hello
Error: The following options cannot be both set: "-a", "-b"
```

Even though this ability has been suggested multiple times over the years (see #257, #509, #1137), it was rejected every time. I do believe that this is something *Click* users should really benefit from. If you choose to approve this suggestion, I will try to implement it.

title: Click raises RuntimeError even when exit code = 0, hence gives error in ipython
body:
When click exits, it [raises a RuntimeError](https://github.com/pallets/click/blob/main/src/click/core.py#L685-L687) even when everything worked ok. Hence, if I wrap a call to a click command inside a `try/except`, this will be picked up as an exception even though nothing went wrong.

This creates a problem with ipython, which catches all exceptions and does some custom handling of them. What happens appears to be: ipython [executes the code](https://github.com/ipython/ipython/blob/7.32.0/IPython/core/interactiveshell.py#L3524), click raises the `RuntimeError`, ipython [catches it](https://github.com/ipython/ipython/blob/7.32.0/IPython/core/ultratb.py#L1108) but because there's no actual error message or traceback, ipython seems to get confused and generates even more exceptions.

Is there a reason why click raises an exception even when the program ran ok and `code == 0`? [I changed the click behaviour very slightly to no longer do so](https://github.com/pallets/click/compare/main...AntonyMilneQB:main) and it fixes this completely, but I'm guessing there's a reason click doesn't do this already?

### Steps to reproduce
1. Put the [README's simple example](https://github.com/pallets/click#a-simple-example) into hello.py
2. Start an ipython session using `ipython`
3. Enter `from hello import hello; hello()`
4. Command executes ok (even with arguments, like `hello(["--count", 3])` but will afterwards produce the following exception ([see full traceback](https://gist.github.com/AntonyMilneQB/805da60db4d15fe7a41951633d95ca74)):
```
ERROR:root:Internal Python error in the inspect module.
Below is the traceback from this internal error.

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/antony_milne/miniconda3/envs/spaceflights/lib/python3.8/site-packages/click/core.py", line 1065, in main
    ctx.exit()
  File "/Users/antony_milne/miniconda3/envs/spaceflights/lib/python3.8/site-packages/click/core.py", line 687, in exit
    raise Exit(code)
click.exceptions.Exit: 0
``` 

Note: that `ipython -m hello` works ok, as does the above flow when using `python`. It's only when running an interactive ipython session that click's RuntimeError is problematic.

### What should happen
No traceback from ipython.

### Environment
- Python version: 3.8.13
- Click version: 8.1.2

title: Flags with `multiple=True` trigger `TypeError`
body:
Adding an option with `is_flag=True`, `is_eager=True`, and `multiple=True` will trigger a `TypeError` in `Parameter.consume_value()` due to bad default value.

```py
import click

def version_handler(ctx, param, value):
    if value:
        print("version_handler", ctx, param, value)
        ctx.exit()

@click.command()
@click.pass_context
@click.option(
    "--version",
    "-V",
    callback=version_handler,
    expose_value=False,
    is_eager=True,
    is_flag=True,
    multiple=True,
)
def main(ctx):
    pass

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
```

When run without the flag, a TypeError is raised:

```
(venv39) jreese@butterfree ~/scratch » python foo.py
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/jreese/scratch/foo.py", line 25, in <module>
    main()
  File "/Users/jreese/scratch/venv39/lib/python3.9/site-packages/click/core.py", line 1130, in __call__
    return self.main(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/Users/jreese/scratch/venv39/lib/python3.9/site-packages/click/core.py", line 1054, in main
    with self.make_context(prog_name, args, **extra) as ctx:
  File "/Users/jreese/scratch/venv39/lib/python3.9/site-packages/click/core.py", line 920, in make_context
    self.parse_args(ctx, args)
  File "/Users/jreese/scratch/venv39/lib/python3.9/site-packages/click/core.py", line 1378, in parse_args
    value, args = param.handle_parse_result(ctx, opts, args)
  File "/Users/jreese/scratch/venv39/lib/python3.9/site-packages/click/core.py", line 2356, in handle_parse_result
    value, source = self.consume_value(ctx, opts)
  File "/Users/jreese/scratch/venv39/lib/python3.9/site-packages/click/core.py", line 2903, in consume_value
    and any(v is _flag_needs_value for v in value)
TypeError: 'bool' object is not iterable
```

Manually setting a better default value, like `default=()`, avoids the type error, but this used to work on 7.x without setting the default value.

Environment:

- Python version: tested on 3.8.6 and 3.9.3
- Click version: worked on 7.1.2; errors on 8.0.4 and 8.1.2

title: Regression of #1603: detection of program name when run with `python -m`
body:
<!--
This issue tracker is a tool to address bugs in Click itself. Please use
Pallets Discord or Stack Overflow for questions about your own code.

Replace this comment with a clear outline of what the bug is.
-->

<!--
Describe how to replicate the bug.

Include a minimal reproducible example that demonstrates the bug.
Include the full traceback if there was an exception.
-->

<!--
Describe the expected behavior that should have happened but didn't.
-->

Environment:

- Python version: 3.10.4
- Click version: 8.1.2

See original bug report #1603 marked as closed with fix, but these steps lead to the same issue with current release, hence my suspicion of a regression. For posterity,

here are my own steps to reproduce leading me there.

I created a Python package with a `src/mypkg/mysubpkg/__main__.py` module file like this:

```python
import click
import click.decorators
import logging
from typing import Any


logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)


@click.command()
@click.option(
    "--logging-level",
    type=click.Choice(["DEBUG", "INFO", "WARNING", "ERROR", "CRITICAL"]),
    default="INFO",
)
def main(**kwargs: Any) -> None:
    """My app"""
    logging.basicConfig(level=logging_level)
    logger.info("Hello world!")


main()
```

Then calling the module results in **actual output**:

```console
$ python -m mypkg.mysubpkg --help
Usage: -m [OPTIONS]
[...]
```

**Expected output**:

```console
$ python -m mypkg.mysubpkg --help
Usage: python -m mypkg.mysubpkg [OPTIONS]
[...]
```
(or something else, equivalent)

title: Click 8.1 changed the parameter order in click.Path
body:
In #1962 (released as 8.1.x) the writable and readable parameters for the `click.Path` constructor changed order (and the executable parameter was not added at the end of the parameter list). This breaks code that was not using kwargs in the constructor.

See for example the breakage from lsst/daf_butler#669.

We have switched to kwargs. The API is not requiring that it only be used with kwargs and so we had not used kwargs previously.

Please consider using the `*` parameter in the APIs that are assumed to be kwargs only as this would enforce the policy.

Environment:

- Python version: 3.8
- Click version: 8.1.1

title: Removal of _unicodefun from the recently 8.1.0 breaks dependees
body:
The recently released `8.1.0` seem to have removed [`_unicodefun`](https://github.com/pallets/click/compare/8.0.4...8.1.0). This causes dependees that expect `_unicodefun` to be there to break.

Any code that uses the current version of [`black`](https://github.com/psf/black/blob/2d62a09e838d2df98961e6e93036abad54f28c5f/setup.py#L99) will break. See log from our CI [build](https://github.com/CodeForAfrica/DebunkBot/runs/5732073408?check_suite_focus=true) below:
```sh
 Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/root/.cache/pre-commit/repoxd97m0e9/py_env-python3/bin/black", line 8, in <module>
    sys.exit(patched_main())
  File "/root/.cache/pre-commit/repoxd97m0e9/py_env-python3/lib/python3.10/site-packages/black/__init__.py", line 1423, in patched_main
    patch_click()
  File "/root/.cache/pre-commit/repoxd97m0e9/py_env-python3/lib/python3.10/site-packages/black/__init__.py", line 1409, in patch_click
    from click import _unicodefun
ImportError: cannot import name '_unicodefun' from 'click' (/root/.cache/pre-commit/repoxd97m0e9/py_env-python3/lib/python3.10/site-packages/click/__init__.py)
```

Also [this](https://github.com/dask/distributed/issues/6013) issue on `distributed` is caused by the same bug.

Going from `8.0.4` to `8.1.0` being a minor release upgrade, I expect `_unicodefun` to be there.

Environment:

- Python version: 3.10
- Click version: 8.1.0

title: Regression: Type errors caused by untyped decorator
body:
With 8.1 we are now getting errors in mypy due to the `.command()` decorator.

Looking at the code (https://github.com/pallets/click/blob/main/src/click/core.py#L1814), it appears to have been changed to a `Union` while adding support for not calling the decorator before the function.

As per the mypy documentation, this should be represented with overloads, rather than a union:
https://mypy.readthedocs.io/en/stable/generics.html?highlight=decorator#decorator-factories

title: `Group` code is executed when subcommand is invoked with `--help` but not through `click.testing.CliRunner`
body:
Consider the following minimal script:
```python
import click

@click.group()
def cli():
    raise RuntimeError()

@cli.command('sub')
def sub():
    click.echo('all good')

if __name__ == '__main__':
    cli()
```
When calling the `--help` for the main command all is fine:
```
(aiida_dev) sph@citadel:~/code/aiida/env/dev/ro-crate-py$ python test_cli.py --help
Usage: test_cli.py [OPTIONS] COMMAND [ARGS]...

Options:
  --help  Show this message and exit.

Commands:
  sub
```
But when calling the `--help` for the `sub` command, the `RuntimeError` is hit:
```
(aiida_dev) sph@citadel:~/code/aiida/env/dev/ro-crate-py$ python test_cli.py sub --help
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/sph/code/aiida/env/dev/ro-crate-py/test_cli.py", line 12, in <module>
    cli()
  File "/home/sph/.virtualenvs/aiida_dev/lib/python3.9/site-packages/click/core.py", line 1128, in __call__
    return self.main(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/home/sph/.virtualenvs/aiida_dev/lib/python3.9/site-packages/click/core.py", line 1053, in main
    rv = self.invoke(ctx)
  File "/home/sph/.virtualenvs/aiida_dev/lib/python3.9/site-packages/click/core.py", line 1656, in invoke
    super().invoke(ctx)
  File "/home/sph/.virtualenvs/aiida_dev/lib/python3.9/site-packages/click/core.py", line 1395, in invoke
    return ctx.invoke(self.callback, **ctx.params)
  File "/home/sph/.virtualenvs/aiida_dev/lib/python3.9/site-packages/click/core.py", line 754, in invoke
    return __callback(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/home/sph/code/aiida/env/dev/ro-crate-py/test_cli.py", line 5, in cli
    raise RuntimeError()
RuntimeError
```
Is this intended behavior? Should the body of the `cli` `Group` be executed if a sub-command receives the `--help` option?
And if this is the intended behavior, how can we properly test for this.
If we invoke `sub` through the `click.testing.CliRunner` the exception is not hit:
```python
In [1]: import click
   ...: 
   ...: @click.group()
   ...: def cli():
   ...:     raise RuntimeError()
   ...: 
   ...: @cli.command('sub')
   ...: def sub():
   ...:     click.echo('all good')
   ...: 

In [2]: from click.testing import CliRunner

In [3]: CliRunner().invoke(sub, ['--help'])
Out[3]: <Result okay>
```

Environment:

- Python version: 3.9.11
- Click version: 8.0.4

title: compstate[insert]="automenu" missing from click 8
body:
In click 7.x the ZSH script used `compstate[insert]="automenu"` (https://github.com/pallets/click/blob/7.x/src/click/_bashcomplete.py#L73) and in click 8.x this is no longer supported (https://github.com/pallets/click/blob/main/src/click/shell_completion.py#L125).

Without this, you can no longer to `in` comparisons on autocompletes.

title: Sign up for GitHub Sponsors
body: I know there is already a Donate link that goes through `psfmember.com`, but it would be really great to donate through GitHub. # Why not psfmember? The current psfmember website requires PayPal (a company I do not do business with) or a personal check (which I don't want to use, and makes it hard to do recurring payments). I really don't want to comment on how bat the UI / UX on that website is, but it is... not ideal. # GitHub Sponsors GitHub already has my payment method, and it makes it VERY easy to set up single-time or recurring payments. It's super seamless, and there are no transaction fees unless the entity making the donation is a business. It takes about 5 minutes total to sign up. https://github.com/sponsors is all you need ## Additional Resources There's a LOT more information on customization available here: * [Announcing GitHub Sponsors: a new way to contribute to open source | The GitHub Blog](https://github.blog/2019-05-23-announcing-github-sponsors-a-new-way-to-contribute-to-open-source/) * [Getting started with GitHub Sponsors | The GitHub Blog](https://github.blog/2020-03-24-getting-started-with-github-sponsors/) * [FAQ with the GitHub Sponsors team | The GitHub Blog](https://github.blog/2019-06-12-faq-with-the-github-sponsors-team/) * [New sponsors-only repositories, custom amounts, and more | The GitHub Blog](https://github.blog/2022-02-02-new-sponsors-only-repositories-custom-amounts-and-more/) ## Sponsorship Made Easy It's ridiculously simple. GitHub already has your payment info, 0% fees for non-companies, and it takes exactly 3 clicks to donate. You don't need to enter ANY data other than how much you want to donate, one-time or recurring, and that's all. If you set up Sponsors for the Organization (`pallets`) you can configure whether your sponsors show up on the right side of the Github landing page. ### Exactly Two Screenshots It's really this easy for people to donate, AND it shows up in a standard, expected place on your repos!

title: Improve type hints
body:
This PR improves the typpe annotation on `@command` decorator so that when `cls` is submitted, the return value is an instance of `cls`.

In addition, as a small tweak, I lowered the requirement on `choices` of `Choice` to `Collection` -- we only need iteration and length. This way `Choice(choices=somedict.keys())` is valid.

- fixes #2211

title: Incorrect type hint when @command uses a custom class
body:
The `@command` decorator is annotated as always returning `Command`.

This is a problem when supplying custom class, e.g.:
```python
@click.command(cls=MyClass)
def foo():
     ...

reveal_type(foo)  # revealed type is `Command`
foo.my_property = 6  # error: `Command` does not have a member `my_property`
```


Environment:

- Python version: any
- Click version: 8.x

title: Add `EnumChoice` parameter type
body:
Added a new ability to be able to create a choice parameter type from enum class.

How does it differ from `Choice`? Enums are the way of python to allow only a finite number of values to be accepted in a given scenario. It seems logical to me that click should offer a `Choice`-like parameter type that gets its values from an enum and returns an enum.

Now, using `click.EnumChoice`, one can create a `Choice`-like parameter that returns an enum instead of a string.
Moreover, once you add a new value to your enum class, it will automatically update as a valid choice for the paramater type.

title: Bump actions/setup-python from 2 to 3

labels.name: dependencies
labels.description: Pull requests that update a dependency file

body:
Bumps [actions/setup-python](https://github.com/actions/setup-python) from 2 to 3.
Release notes

Sourced from actions/setup-python's releases.

v3.0.0

What's Changed

  • Update default runtime to node16 (actions/setup-python#340)
  • Update package-lock.json file version to 2, @types/node to 16.11.25 and typescript to 4.2.3 (actions/setup-python#341)
  • Remove legacy pypy2 and pypy3 keywords (actions/setup-python#342)

Breaking Changes

With the update to Node 16, all scripts will now be run with Node 16 rather than Node 12.

This new major release removes support of legacy pypy2 and pypy3 keywords. Please use more specific and flexible syntax to specify a PyPy version:

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    strategy:
      matrix:
        python-version:
        - 'pypy-2.7' # the latest available version of PyPy that supports Python 2.7
        - 'pypy-3.8' # the latest available version of PyPy that supports Python 3.8
        - 'pypy-3.8-v7.3.8' # Python 3.8 and PyPy 7.3.8
    steps:
    - uses: actions/checkout@v2
    - uses: actions/setup-python@v3
      with:
        python-version: ${{ matrix.python-version }}

See more usage examples in the documentation

Update primary and restore keys for pip

In scope of this release we include a version of python in restore and primary cache keys for pip. Besides, we add temporary fix for Windows caching issue, that the pip cache dir command returns non zero exit code or writes to stderr. Moreover we updated node-fetch dependency.

Update actions/cache version to 1.0.8

We have updated actions/cache dependency version to 1.0.8 to support 10GB cache upload

Support caching dependencies

This release introduces dependency caching support (actions/setup-python#266)

Caching dependencies.

The action has a built-in functionality for caching and restoring pip/pipenv dependencies. The cache input is optional, and caching is turned off by default.

Besides, this release introduces dependency caching support for mono repos and repositories with complex structure.

By default, the action searches for the dependency file (requirements.txt for pip or Pipfile.lock for pipenv) in the whole repository. Use the cache-dependency-path input for cases when you want to override current behaviour and use different file for hash generation (for example requirements-dev.txt). This input supports wildcards or a list of file names for caching multiple dependencies.

Caching pip dependencies:

steps:
- uses: actions/checkout@v2
- uses: actions/setup-python@v2
  with:
    python-version: '3.9'
</tr></table>

... (truncated)

Commits
  • 0ebf233 Remove legacy PyPy input (#342)
  • 665cd78 Update lockfileversion (#341)
  • 93cb78f Update to node16 (#340)

title: documentation about entry points is unclear
body:
First, thanks for making an awesome tool! Click made knocking together a CLI for my masters work trivial. 

These documentation questions are an effort to clarify some of the language in the [setuptools](https://click.palletsprojects.com/en/8.0.x/setuptools/) and [shell completion](https://click.palletsprojects.com/en/8.0.x/shell-completion/?highlight=tab%20complete#enabling-completion) sections, to reduce friction for new users like me. 

1. Though **Shell Completion** depends on users installing through a setuptools entrypoint, and refers to the **Setuptools Integration** docs, the terminology is not aligned between the two sets of examples. **Scripts in Packages** refers to the package `yourpackage`, a subpackage `scripts`, a module `yourscript`, and a click command `cli`. Shell Completion refers to `PROG_NAME`, "the executable name in uppercase...". Does `PROG_NAME` map to the the name of the package `yourscript`, the entrypoint `yourscript`, the command `cli`, or something else entirely? Clarification of exactly what the "executable name" is here would be very helpful.
2. In the **Scripts in Packages** example, it is unclear that the `console_scripts` key is a "default" value, and not something package-specific. For users who have worked with entrypoints in setup.py before, this is probably obvious, but for newcomers there's no visual way to differentiate "standard" values from semantically meaningful ones in this example. A single-sentence note clarifying would help.

- Python version: 3.8
- Click version: 8

title: rewrite the parser
body:
Click currently uses a modified copy of optparse to parse command line arguments. In order to use it, Click creates an entire optparse class structure mirroring the structure that users write, which seems like unnecessary overhead. Click also goes beyond what optparse was intended for, which means there's a lot of working around how optparse works. There are old issues about the processing being an issue, and newer features are also affected because it's hard to manage whether the parser or the processing will get values or raise errors.

Most of the code in our parser copy isn't even the actual parsing code, it's all the optparse equivalent objects to Click's objects. I've started working on a new parser that works directly from the Click objects, instead of constructing a separate parser structure.

The following open issues are related, although I'm not guaranteeing that they'll all be immediately fixed with the rewrite. Some of them are also affected by the processing pipeline, which happens after parsing.

* https://github.com/pallets/click/issues/473
* https://github.com/pallets/click/issues/590
* https://github.com/pallets/click/issues/602
* https://github.com/pallets/click/issues/611
* https://github.com/pallets/click/issues/619
* https://github.com/pallets/click/issues/680
* https://github.com/pallets/click/issues/742
* https://github.com/pallets/click/issues/1269
* https://github.com/pallets/click/issues/1279
* https://github.com/pallets/click/issues/1322
* https://github.com/pallets/click/issues/1340

* https://github.com/pallets/click/issues/1489

title: command decorator params argument
body:
The `@command` decorator accepts the `params` argument that `Command` accepts, instead of raising a `TypeError`. Params added with `@option` and `@argument` are appended to the end of the list if given. This makes the signatures match, and makes it easier to add common options to multiple commands.

closes #2131

title: refactor command decorator
body: A few more refactors I noticed after #2151. The decorator code was in a separate function but only called in one place, so inlining that means one less frame on the stack when initializing commands. Since we want to avoid processing the help text until it's rendered, pass on `f.__doc__` directly instead of calling `inspect.getdoc`.

title: glob expansion on Windows doesn't fail on invalid values
body:
When we do glob pattern expansion on Windows, don't raise an error when attempting to expand a value that is an invalid pattern.

closes #2195

title: Add Bash completion support fot bash versions older than 4.4
body:
Hi guys, 
I wanted to know why support for Bash version older than 4.4 was deliberately removed?
I think there are a lot of people who use older versions of the Bash and when they start getting familiar with Click they find autocompletions don't work out of the box. Despite having an extensible completions system, newbies to Click may decide to leave the package rather than write their own extension. It pushes new people away from using Click.

Maybe you should abandon the version check and return to choosing an option in the [shell script](https://github.com/pallets/click/blob/43e40c05a4b94c6aa497dc7bba62b7d69b7e35ec/src/click/_bashcomplete.py#L29) ?

Alternatively, maybe it's worth adding a small package to the click-contrib that would patch the original BashComplete ?
I can do it if needed.

title: remove utf-8 detection
body: closes #2198

title: remove `_unicodefun`
body:
Same as https://github.com/pallets/werkzeug/issues/1760, Python 3.7+ picks UTF-8 instead of ASCII for misconfigured systems. Since we are dropping Python 3.6, we can drop the check.

```
~ 
❯ LANG= LC_ALL= python3.6 -c 'import locale, codecs; print(codecs.lookup(locale.getpreferredencoding()).name)'
ascii

~ 
❯ LANG= LC_ALL= python3.7 -c 'import locale, codecs; print(codecs.lookup(locale.getpreferredencoding()).name)'
utf-8
```

The command I'm running in context is

```
but it can replicated without using pipenv or pytest and produce the same exception. 

Running

```
results in
```text
  File "C:\Users\xxx\.virtualenvs\xxx-3g_HEZBh\lib\site-packages\click\utils.py", line 572, in _expand_args
    matches = glob(arg, recursive=glob_recursive)

Expected behavior - if expansion fails, treat it as an empty glob match. Something like this but without the bare except catch.

def _expand_args(args):

title: `ctx.get_parameter_source()` not recognized by mypy
body:
When using `ctx.get_parameter_source()`, mypy throws the following error:
```
"Context" has no attribute "get_parameter_source"  [attr-defined]
```

Minimal example:
```py
import click                        


def foo(ctx: click.Context):
    ctx.get_parameter_source("bar")
```

This shouldn't happen, because the method exists and the code executes fine (if the proper `@click.command` decorator is added).

title: `ctx.color` is ignored in `ClickException.show()`
body:
I have tried to set `ctx.color = True` as suggested in #1090 in order to enable colour output in Gitlab CI. This worked out great for normal `click.secho` but unfortunately it does not work for output generated via raising `ClickException` subclass. Essentially the `echo` inside `ClickException.show()` ignores `ctx.color`.

After some digging, I am almost sure this is because the `get_current_context` returns `None`, there is no context when exceptions are handled:
https://github.com/pallets/click/blob/49164faca678dd476f1b11a2584fd0e1c6be70b2/src/click/globals.py#L63

## Test code
```python
import click
from click import ClickException


class CLIError(ClickException):
    def format_message(self) -> str:
        return click.style(self.message, fg='red')


@click.command()
@click.option('--ansi', is_flag=True)
@click.pass_context
def cli(ctx, ansi):
    if ansi:
        ctx.color = True

    click.secho('some output', fg='green')

    raise CLIError('some error')


if __name__ == '__main__':
    cli()
```

## Test cases
1. `python test.py`
2. `python test.py --ansi`
3. `python test.py &> test.log; cat test.log`
4. `python test.py --ansi &> test.log; cat test.log`

## Expected behaviour
In all cases except 3) there is a green `some output` and red `some error` in output.

In 3) there is no colouring.

## Actual behaviour
Everything is as expected except 4) where `some error` is not coloured.

## Environment
- Python version: 3.7.9
- Click version: 8.0.3

title: Add click.Path option that allows checking for executable flag
body:
[`click.Path`](https://click.palletsprojects.com/en/8.0.x/api/#click.Path) already allows checking whether a path points to a directory ( `dir_okay`) or a file ( `file_okay`) and whether it is `readable` and/or `writeable`. I would suggest to add an additional `executable` flag that would check if the executable bit is set for the file or directory the path points to.

This surely can be achieved via a custom type, but it seems to me that this would be a valuable extension of `click.Path` as it would lead to all three access modes being checkable via click.  
I am happy to contribute to an implementation, if there is any interest in this.

title: [Feature] Set progressbar ETA manually
body:
Description
========
One should be able to set `click.progressbar` ETA (estimated time of arrival) **manually**.

Why?
====
Sometimes you want to use `click.progressbar` when you know that processing each element in this bar can be done in very different time spans (some elements take shorter time to process while others take a long time). You still want to show ETA, but you know that the automatic way *Click* is calculating this ETA is inaccurate.

In my personal use case, I have statistics on each task on how long it normally takes, so I can calculate ETA **historically** pretty easy.

Proposed Syntax
===========
```python
import click


@click.command()
def my_command():
    with click.progressbar(length=20) as bar:
        for i in bar:
            time.sleep(0.5)
            bar.eta = eta_in_seconds
```

title: Click option completion callback doesn't have access to context.params for parsed values of already typed arguments.
body:
Click option completion callback doesn't have access to context.params for parsed values of already typed arguments during shell completion:

```python
import click

def test_completer(ctx, param, incomplete):
    import sys
    print(f"1: {param= }", file=sys.stderr)
    print(f"2: {incomplete= }", file=sys.stderr)
    print(f"3: {ctx.params = }", file=sys.stderr)
    return []

@click.command()
@click.argument('type', shell_complete=test_completer)
@click.option('--test', shell_complete=test_completer)
def app(type, count):
    pass
```

Output:
```
app foo --test [TAB] [TAB]
1: param= <Option test>
2: incomplete= ''
3: ctx.params = {'type': None, 'test': None}
```
Thus the context inside option callback does not have access to already typed argument.

But vice versa works:
```
app --test bar [TAB] [TAB] 
1: param= <Argument type>
2: incomplete= ''
3: ctx.params = {'test': 'bar', 'type': None}
```
The context inside argument callback have access to already typed option.

I think it should be the same in both cases.

Environment:

- Python version: 3.8
- Click version: 8.0.3

title: Show help for all commands (follow-up)
body:
This is a follow-up on #1449.

> To get an overview of a program's usage, it would be helpful to print help for all commands at once rather than having to run, e.g. `script.py command1 --help`, `script.py command2 --help`, etc.
> 
> This feature is important because the default top-level help doesn't indicate which commands have options, so it doesn't give a good overview of the program's functionality.

Counting the related questions and answers on the Web, there is significant interest to provide a solution for this problem.

## Solution Example

Based on the [approach from SO](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/57810659/), this could be a fully working solution:

```python
def all_help(ctx, param, value):
    """Show usage for all commands and exit."""

    def collect_help(cmd, parent=None):
        ctx = click.core.Context(cmd, info_name=cmd.name, parent=parent)
        if parent:
            click.echo()
        else:
            ctx.help_option_names.remove('--help')
        click.echo(cmd.get_help(ctx))
        commands = getattr(cmd, 'commands', {})
        for sub in commands.values():
            collect_help(sub, ctx)

    if value:
        collect_help(ctx.command)


@click.group(click.utils._detect_program_name(), invoke_without_command=True, no_args_is_help=True)
@click.option("--help", is_flag=True, expose_value=False, callback=all_help, help=all_help.__doc__)
def main():
    """Your CLI application starts here."""
```

The above implementation shows the simple help screen (group help) when invoked w/o arguments and the full help screen with `prog_name --help`.

To reduce the clutter of the resulting screen, the `--help` option of all subcommands is suppressed. The above solution saves us from adding `@click.help_option(hidden=True)` decorators on each command.

## Criticism

The verbose argument list in the `@click.group(...)` decorator is not particularly elegant, be but it's unfortunately needed to:

- suppress an `Error: Missing command.` when using `--help` on the main group, and
- display the correct `prog_name` for all commands in the help screen (the name of the group _function_ is used, otherwise).

## Proposal

Probably the simplest thing to do would be to add the above code sample to the Click documentation. Potential places:

- [Options](https://click.palletsprojects.com/en/latest/options/) chapter
- [Commands and Groups](https://click.palletsprojects.com/en/latest/commands/) chapter
- [Examples](https://click.palletsprojects.com/en/latest/quickstart/#screencast-and-examples) in Quickstart

Alternatively, we turn the above code into a decorator and add it to the Click code base.

Would you be open for a PR on either extending the docs or adding a decorator as explained?

title: Result stderr is not captured
body:
I'm testing my click application and have got several instances of the following code:
```
try:
    <thing that raises exception>
except SpecificException as err:
    click.echo(str(err), err=True)
    exit(1)
```

But when testing this through pytest and the CliRunner it complains that stderr is not being captured:
```
@pytest.fixture
def runner():
    yield CliRunner()

def test_db_create(runner):
    call = runner.invoke(cli, ["database", "create", db.name])
    assert call.exit_code == 1
    assert isinstance(call.exception, SystemExit)
    assert call.stderr == "My Error Message"
```

Traceback:
```
self = <Result SystemExit(1)>

    @property
    def stderr(self) -> str:
        """The standard error as unicode string."""
        if self.stderr_bytes is None:
>           raise ValueError("stderr not separately captured")
